		This shows that <span class="css">!important</span> declarations have a function also within author style sheets. 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- c>/* From the user’s style sheet */</c->
p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>text-indent</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>1</c-><c- k>em</c-> !important <c- p>}</c->
p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font-style</c-><c- p>:</c-> italic !important <c- p>}</c->
p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font-size</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>18</c-><c- k>pt</c-> <c- p>}</c->

<c- c>/* From the author’s style sheet */</c->
p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>text-indent</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>1.5</c-><c- k>em</c-> !important <c- p>}</c->
p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font</c-><c- p>:</c-> normal <c- m>12</c-><c- k>pt</c-> sans-serif !important <c- p>}</c->
p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font-size</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>24</c-><c- k>pt</c-> <c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <table class="data">
     <thead>
      <tr>
       <th>Property 
       <th>Winning value 
     <tbody>
      <tr>
       <th><a class="property" data-link-type="propdesc" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-3/#propdef-text-indent" id="ref-for-propdef-text-indent">text-indent</a> 
       <td><span class="css">1em</span> 
      <tr>
       <th><a class="property" data-link-type="propdesc" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#propdef-font-style" id="ref-for-propdef-font-style①">font-style</a> 
       <td><a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#valdef-font-style-italic" id="ref-for-valdef-font-style-italic">italic</a> 
      <tr>
       <th><a class="property" data-link-type="propdesc" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-5/#descdef-font-face-font-size" id="ref-for-descdef-font-face-font-size③">font-size</a> 
       <td><span class="css">12pt</span> 
      <tr>
       <th><a class="property" data-link-type="propdesc" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#propdef-font-family" id="ref-for-propdef-font-family①">font-family</a> 
       <td><a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#valdef-font-family-sans-serif" id="ref-for-valdef-font-family-sans-serif">sans-serif</a> 
    </table>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4" id="layering"><span class="secno">6.4. </span><span class="content"> Cascade Layers</span><a class="self-link" href="#layering"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>In the same way that <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#origin" id="ref-for-origin①⓪">cascade origins</a> provide a balance of power
	between user and author styles, <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-local-lt="layer" id="cascade-layers">cascade layers</dfn> provide a structured way
	to organize and balance concerns within a single origin.
	Rules within a single <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers⑥">cascade layer</a> cascade together,
	without interleaving with style rules outside the layer.</p>
   <p>Authors can create layers to represent element defaults,
	third-party libraries, themes, components,
	overrides, and other styling concerns—<wbr>and are able to re-order the cascade of layers in an explicit way,
	without altering selectors or specificity within each layer,
	or relying on source-order to resolve conflicts across layers.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-d1251f4f">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-d1251f4f"></a> For example, the following generates an explicit <span class="css">reset</span> layer,
		with lower cascade weight than any unlayered styles: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight">audio <c- p>{</c->
  <c- c>/* specificity of 0,0,1 - implicit (final) layer */</c->
  display: flex<c- p>;</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> reset <c- p>{</c->
  audio<c- p>[</c->controls<c- p>]</c-> <c- p>{</c->
    <c- c>/* specificity of 0,1,1 - explicit "reset" layer */</c->
    display: block<c- p>;</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>The unlayered declarations on the <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/media.html#audio" id="ref-for-audio">audio</a></code> element take precedence
		over the explicitly layered declarations on <code>audio[controls]</code> —<wbr>even though the unlayered styles have a lower specificity,
		and come first in the source order.</p>
   </div>
   <p>Name-defining <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-syntax-3/#at-rule" id="ref-for-at-rule">at-rules</a> such as <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-animations-1/#at-ruledef-keyframes" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-keyframes">@keyframes</a> or <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-5/#at-font-face-rule" id="ref-for-at-font-face-rule">@font-face</a> that are defined inside <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers⑦">cascade layers</a> also use the layer order when resolving name collisions.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-3ebc99c8">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-3ebc99c8"></a> For example,
		authors could override the animation from a framework,
		by providing keyframes with the same name in a higher-priority layer: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- c>/* establish the layer order, so the "override" layer takes precedence */</c->
<c- n>@layer</c-> framework<c- p>,</c-> override<c- p>;</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> override <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@keyframes</c-> slide-left <c- p>{</c->
    from <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>translate</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
    to <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>translate</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>-100</c-><c- k>%</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> framework <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@keyframes</c-> slide-left <c- p>{</c->
    from <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>margin-left</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
    to <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>margin-left</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>-100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

.sidebar <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>animation</c-><c- p>:</c-> slide-left <c- m>300</c-><c- k>ms</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>In this case the <span class="css">override</span> layer
		has a higher cascade priority than the <span class="css">framework</span> layer,
		so <code>slide-left</code> will animate
		using the <code>translate</code> property rather than <code>margin-left</code>.</p>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.1" id="layer-declaration"><span class="secno">6.4.1. </span><span class="content"> Declaring Cascade Layers</span><a class="self-link" href="#layer-declaration"></a></h4>
   <p>Cascade layers can be declared:</p>
   <ul>
    <li data-md>
     <p>using an <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import①④">@import</a> rule with the <span class="css">layer</span> keyword or <span class="css">layer()</span> function,
assigning the contents of the imported file into that layer.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>using a <a href="#layer-block">@layer block at-rule</a>,
assigning its child style rules into that layer.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>using a <a href="#layer-empty">@layer statement at-rule</a>,
declaring a named layer without assigning any rules.</p>
   </ul>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-3d8c81e9"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-3d8c81e9"></a> Provide an attribute for assigning link or style elements to cascade layers? <a href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/5853">[Issue #w3c/csswg-drafts#5853]</a></p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.2" id="layer-names"><span class="secno">6.4.2. </span><span class="content"> Layer Naming and Nesting</span><a class="self-link" href="#layer-names"></a></h4>
   <p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers⑧">cascade layer</a> has a <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport id="layer-name">layer name</dfn>,
	which is an ordered list representing each level of layer nesting,
	each segment of which can be named (as a <a data-link-type="dfn">CSS identifier</a>)
	or anonymous.
	(Thus, when a layer is nested inside of another layer,
	this concatenates their names.)
	One layer is nested in another
	when it is declared within the scope of another layer,
	e.g. an <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer②">@layer</a> rule inside another <span class="css" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer③">@layer</span>,
	a layered <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import①⑤">@import</a> inside a layered import,
	or an <span class="css" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer④">@layer</span> rule inside a layered import.</p>
   <p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name">Layer names</a> represent the same <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers⑨">cascade layer</a> if they contain the same segments in the same order;
	however anonymous segments have unique identities for each occurrence.
	Note that nesting can cause multiple layers to share the same anonymous segment.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-8b497e80">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-8b497e80"></a> Explicit layer identifiers provide a way
		to assign multiple style blocks to a single layer.
		In the following example,
		the contents of <code>headings.css</code> and <code>links.css</code> are cascaded within the same layer as the <code>audio[controls]</code> rule: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>headings.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->default<c- p>);</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>links.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->default<c- p>);</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> default <c- p>{</c->
  audio<c- p>[</c->controls<c- p>]</c-> <c- p>{</c->
    <c- k>display</c-><c- p>:</c-> block<c- p>;</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="example-23b0f30e">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-23b0f30e"></a> In this example,
		the nested <span class="css">framework.base</span> layer is distinct
		from the top-level <span class="css">base</span> layer: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> base <c- p>{</c->
  p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>max-width</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>70</c-><c- k>ch</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> framework <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> base <c- p>{</c->
    p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>margin-block</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>0.75</c-><c- k>em</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->

  <c- n>@layer</c-> theme <c- p>{</c->
    p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> #222<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>The resulting layers can be represented as a tree:</p>
    <ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">base</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">framework</span></p>
      <ol>
       <li data-md>
        <p><span class="css">base</span></p>
       <li data-md>
        <p><span class="css">theme</span></p>
      </ol>
    </ol>
    <p>or as a flat list with nested identifiers:</p>
    <ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">base</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">framework.base</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">framework.theme</span></p>
    </ol>
   </div>
   <p>Syntactically, an explicit <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name①">layer name</a> is represented
	by the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name①">&lt;layer-name></a> in <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer⑤">@layer</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import①⑥">@import</a> rules,
	which is a period-separated list of <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-ident" id="ref-for-typedef-ident">&lt;ident></a> tokens
	with no intervening white space:</p>
<pre class="prod"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-layer-name"><a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name②">&lt;layer-name></a></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-ident" id="ref-for-typedef-ident①">&lt;ident></a> [ '.' <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-ident" id="ref-for-typedef-ident②">&lt;ident></a> ]<a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-zero-plus" id="ref-for-mult-zero-plus">*</a>
</pre>
   <p>The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#css-wide-keywords" id="ref-for-css-wide-keywords①">CSS-wide keywords</a> are reserved for future use,
	and cause the rule to be invalid at parse time
	if used as an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-ident" id="ref-for-typedef-ident③">&lt;ident></a> in the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name③">&lt;layer-name></a>.
	When multiple identifiers are concatenated with a period,
	this is a shorthand representing those layers nested in order.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-cd070ab3">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-cd070ab3"></a> 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> framework <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> default <c- p>{</c->
     p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>margin-block</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>0.75</c-><c- k>em</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->

  <c- n>@layer</c-> theme <c- p>{</c->
    p <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> #222<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> framework.theme <c- p>{</c->
  <c- c>/* These styles will be added to the theme layer inside the framework layer */</c->
  blockquote <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> rebeccapurple<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> A nested layer cannot “escape” its parent layer
	to reference layers outside itself.</p>
   <h5 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.2.1" id="unnamed-layers"><span class="secno">6.4.2.1. </span><span class="content"> Anonymous Layers</span><a class="self-link" href="#unnamed-layers"></a></h5>
   <p>When a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer⑥">@layer</a> rule omits its <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name④">&lt;layer-name></a>,
	or an <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import①⑦">@import</a> rule uses the <span class="css">layer</span> keyword (which does not provide a <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name⑤">&lt;layer-name></span>),
	its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name②">layer name</a> gains a unique anonymous segment;
	it therefore cannot be referenced from the outside.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-787042b6">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-787042b6"></a> Each occurrence of an anonymous layer declaration
		represents a unique cascade layer,
		thus: 
    <ul>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Multiple unnamed layer rules
place their styles into separate layers,
as each occurrence is referencing a distinct anonymous layer name.</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- c>/* layer 1 */</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- n>@layer</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- c>/* layer 2 */</c-> <c- p>}</c->
</pre>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Within a single unnamed layer,
child layers with the same name refer to the same cascade layer,
because they share the same anonymous parent layer.</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> foo <c- p>{</c-> <c- c>/* layer 1 */</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> foo <c- p>{</c-> <c- c>/* also layer 1 */</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Whereas in separate unnamed layers,
child layers with the same name refer to different cascade layers,
because they have distinct anonymous parent layers.</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> foo <c- p>{</c-> <c- c>/* layer 1 */</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
<c- n>@layer</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> foo <c- p>{</c-> <c- c>/* layer 2 */</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    </ul>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="example-52455707">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-52455707"></a> A layer declared without a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name⑥">&lt;layer-name></a> does not provide any external hook for re-arranging or adding styles. 
    <p>While this can be a mere convenience for brevity,
		it can also be used by teams as a way to force an organizing convention
		(all code in that layer must be defined in the same place),
		or by libraries wanting to merge &amp; hide a set of internal “private” layers
		that they don’t want exposed to author manipulation:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- c>/* bootstrap-base.css */</c->
<c- c>/* unnamed wrapper layers around each sub-file */</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>base-forms.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> layer<c- p>;</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>base-links.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> layer<c- p>;</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>base-headings.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> layer<c- p>;</c->
</pre>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- c>/* bootstrap.css */</c->
<c- c>/* the internal names are hidden from access, subsumed in "base" */</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>bootstrap-base.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->base<c- p>);</c->
</pre>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- c>/* author.css */</c->
<c- c>/* author has access to bootstrap.base layer, but not into unnamed layers */</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>bootstrap.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->bootstrap<c- p>);</c->

<c- c>/* Adds additional styles to the bootstrap layer: */</c->
<c- n>@layer</c-> bootstrap <c- p>{</c->...<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.3" id="layer-ordering"><span class="secno">6.4.3. </span><span class="content"> Layer Ordering</span><a class="self-link" href="#layer-ordering"></a></h4>
   <p>Cascade layers are sorted
	by the order in which they first are declared,
	with nested layers grouped within their parent layers
	before any unlayered rules.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-ffb1a154">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-ffb1a154"></a> Given the following layer rules: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- c>/* unlayered styles come last in the layer order */</c->
h1 <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> darkslateblue<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> reset.type <c- p>{</c->
  strong <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font-weight</c-><c- p>:</c-> bold<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> framework <c- p>{</c->
  .title <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font-weight</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>100</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->

  <c- n>@layer</c-> theme <c- p>{</c->
    h1<c- p>,</c-> h2 <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> maroon<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> reset <c- p>{</c->
  <c- p>[</c->hidden<c- p>]</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>display</c-><c- p>:</c-> none<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>The outer layers are sorted first,
		with any unlayered style rules
		added to an implicit outer layer which
		has higher priority than (comes after) the explicit layers:</p>
    <ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">reset</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">framework</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>(implicit outer layer)</p>
    </ol>
    <p>Within each layer,
		nested layers are sorted in appearance order,
		and style rules without further nesting
		are similarly added to an implicit sub-layer
		after the explicitly nested layers:</p>
    <ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">reset.type</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">reset</span> (implicit sub-layer)</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">framework.theme</span></p>
     <li data-md>
      <p><span class="css">framework</span> (implicit sub-layer)</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>(implicit outer layer)</p>
    </ol>
   </div>
   <p>Layers that are defined inside of a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-conditional/#conditional-group-rule" id="ref-for-conditional-group-rule①">conditional group rule</a> do not contribute to the layer order unless the condition is true
	or unless the <span id="ref-for-conditional-group-rule②">conditional group rule</span> can evaluate differently
	for different elements in the document.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> Since the layer order is global to the document,
	any layers defined inside an element-sensitive <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-conditional/#conditional-group-rule" id="ref-for-conditional-group-rule③">conditional group rule</a> need to be accommodated when establishing the global layer order,
	regardless of the rule’s condition.
	Conditions that are global to the document, however
	(such as <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-conditional/#at-ruledef-media" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-media①">@media</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-conditional/#at-ruledef-supports" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-supports①">@supports</a>)
	can accommodate such <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer⑦">@layer</a> rules conditionally.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-87e2d331">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-87e2d331"></a> For example,
		the following layer order
		will depend on which media conditions match: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@media</c-> <c- p>(</c->min-width: <c- m>30</c-><c- k>em</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> layout <c- p>{</c->
    .title <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>font-size</c-><c- p>:</c-> x-large<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@media</c-> <c- p>(</c->prefers-color-scheme: dark<c- p>)</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> theme <c- p>{</c->
    .title <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> white<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> theme<c- p>,</c-> layout<c- p>;</c->
</pre>
    <p>If the first media-query matches based on viewport dimensions,
		then the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-contain-1/#valdef-contain-layout" id="ref-for-valdef-contain-layout">layout</a> layer will come first in the layer order.
		If the color-scheme preference query matches,
		or if neither condition is true,
		then <span class="css">theme</span> will come first in the layer order.</p>
    <p>Authors who want to avoid this behavior can establish
		an explicit ordering of layers in advance,
		and avoid defining new layers inside conditional rules.</p>
   </div>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers①⓪">Cascade layers</a> are scoped to their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#origin" id="ref-for-origin①①">origin</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#encapsulation-contexts" id="ref-for-encapsulation-contexts④">context</a>,
	so the ordering of layers in the light DOM has no impact
	on the order of identically-named layers in the shadow DOM
	(and vice versa).</p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-e29f5f96"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-e29f5f96"></a> Allow authors to explicitly place unlayered styles in the layer order <a href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6323">[Issue #6323]</a></p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.4" id="at-layer"><span class="secno">6.4.4. </span><span class="content"> Declaring Layers Inline: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer⑧">@layer</a> rule</span><a class="self-link" href="#at-layer"></a></h4>
   <p>The <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="at-rule" data-export id="at-ruledef-layer">@layer</dfn> rule
	declares a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers①①">cascade layer</a>, with the option to assign style rules.</p>
   <h5 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.4.1" id="layer-block"><span class="secno">6.4.4.1. </span><span class="content"> Assigning Styles Inline: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer⑨">@layer</a> block at-rule</span><a class="self-link" href="#layer-block"></a></h5>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①⓪">@layer</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-syntax-3/#block-at-rule" id="ref-for-block-at-rule">block at-rule</a> assigns its child style rules to a particular named <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers①②">cascade layer</a>.
	This block layer-assignment syntax is:</p>
<pre class="prod">@layer <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name⑦">&lt;layer-name></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt③">?</a> {
  <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-syntax-3/#typedef-stylesheet" id="ref-for-typedef-stylesheet">&lt;stylesheet></a>
}
</pre>
   <p>Such <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①①">@layer</a> block rules have the same restrictions and processing
	as a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-conditional/#conditional-group-rule" id="ref-for-conditional-group-rule④">conditional group rule</a> <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-conditional-3">[CSS-CONDITIONAL-3]</a> with a true condition.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-149ef997">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-149ef997"></a> For example, <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①②">@layer</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css3-conditional/#at-ruledef-media" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-media②">@media</a> can be mixed: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> framework <c- p>{</c->
  h1<c- p>,</c-> h2 <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> maroon<c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> white<c- p>;}</c->

  <c- n>@media</c-> <c- p>(</c->prefers-color-scheme: dark<c- p>)</c-> <c- p>{</c->
    h1<c- p>,</c-> h2 <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> red<c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> black<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①③">@layer</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-syntax-3/#block-at-rule" id="ref-for-block-at-rule①">block at-rules</a> cannot be interleaved with <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import①⑧">@import</a> rules.</p>
   <h5 class="heading settled" data-level="6.4.4.2" id="layer-empty"><span class="secno">6.4.4.2. </span><span class="content"> Declaring Without Styles: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①④">@layer</a> statement at-rule</span><a class="self-link" href="#layer-empty"></a></h5>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①⑤">@layer</a> rule can also be used to define new layers
	without assigning any style rules, by providing only the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name③">layer name</a>:</p>
<pre class="prod">@layer <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-layer-name" id="ref-for-typedef-layer-name⑧">&lt;layer-name></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-comma" id="ref-for-mult-comma">#</a>;
</pre>
   <p>Such empty <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①⑥">@layer</a> rules are allowed before <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import①⑨">@import</a> and <span class="css">@namespace</span> rules
	(after the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-syntax-3/#at-ruledef-charset" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-charset①">@charset</a> rule, if any)
	as well as everywhere <span class="css" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①⑦">@layer</span> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-syntax-3/#block-at-rule" id="ref-for-block-at-rule②">block at-rules</a> are allowed.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> No <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①⑧">@layer</a> rules are allowed between <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import②⓪">@import</a> and <span class="css">@namespace</span> rules.
	Any <span class="css" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer①⑨">@layer</span> rule that comes after an <span class="css" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import②①">@import</span> or <span class="css">@namespace</span> rule
	will cause any subsequent <span class="css" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import②②">@import</span> or <span class="css">@namespace</span> rules to be ignored.</p>
   <p>Unlike the <a href="#layer-block">block syntax</a>,
	multiple comma-separated layer names can be provided in this syntax,
	declaring each of the layers in the order specified.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> Since layer ordering is defined by first occurrence of the layer name
	(see <a href="#layer-ordering">§ 6.4.3 Layer Ordering</a>),
	this rule allows a page to declare the order of its layers up front,
	so that their order is apparent without having to read the entire style sheet.
	It also allows inline layers to be interleaved with imported layers,
	which is not possible with the <a href="#layer-block">block syntax</a>.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-aa4a55a5">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-aa4a55a5"></a> The statement syntax
		allows establishing a layer order in advance,
		regardless of the order in which style rules are added to each layer.
		It can be helpful to establish that layer order in advance,
		before any <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import②③">@import</a> rules.
		In this example,
		the imported <code>theme.css</code> style rules will override
		any rules added in the later <span class="css">default</span> block
		since the order of layers has already been established: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> default<c- p>,</c-> theme<c- p>,</c-> components<c- p>;</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>theme.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->theme<c- p>);</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> default <c- p>{</c->
  audio<c- p>[</c->controls<c- p>]</c-> <c- p>{</c->
    <c- k>display</c-><c- p>:</c-> block<c- p>;</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>It’s also possible to have <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import②④">@import</a> rules
		help establish the order,
		by placing them between <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer②⓪">@layer</a> rules.
		This example will have the same result:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> default<c- p>;</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>theme.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->theme<c- p>);</c->
<c- n>@layer</c-> components<c- p>;</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> default <c- p>{</c->
  audio<c- p>[</c->controls<c- p>]</c-> <c- p>{</c->
    <c- k>display</c-><c- p>:</c-> block<c- p>;</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>However, <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-import" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-import②⑤">@import</a> and <span class="css">@namespace</span> rules must be consecutive,
		without any intervening rules.
		The following is invalid:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>default.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->default<c- p>);</c->
<c- n>@layer</c-> theme<c- p>;</c->
<c- n>@import</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>components.css</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- nf>layer</c-><c- p>(</c->components<c- p>);</c->

<c- n>@layer</c-> theme <c- p>{</c->
  audio<c- p>[</c->controls<c- p>]</c-> <c- p>{</c->
    <c- k>display</c-><c- p>:</c-> block<c- p>;</c->
  <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="6.5" id="preshint"><span class="secno">6.5. </span><span class="content"> Precedence of Non-CSS Presentational Hints</span><a class="self-link" href="#preshint"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The UA may choose to honor presentational hints in a source document’s markup,
	for example the <code>bgcolor</code> attribute or <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/text-level-semantics.html#the-s-element" id="ref-for-the-s-element">s</a></code> element in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-html">[HTML]</a>.
	All document language-based styling must be translated to corresponding CSS rules
	and enter the cascade as rules in either
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-ua" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-ua③">UA-origin</a> or a special-purpose <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport id="author-presentational-hint-origin">author presentational hint origin</dfn> between the regular <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-user" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-user④">user origin</a> and the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author④">author origin</a>.
	For the purpose of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade③">cascading</a> this <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#author-presentational-hint-origin" id="ref-for-author-presentational-hint-origin">author presentational hint origin</a> is treated as an independent <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#origin" id="ref-for-origin①②">origin</a>,
	but for the purpose of the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert">revert</a> keyword
	it is considered part of the <span id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author⑤">author origin</span>.</p>
   <p>A document language may define whether such a presentational hint
	enters the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade④">cascade</a> as <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-ua" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-ua④">UA-origin</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author⑥">author-origin</a>;
	if so, the UA must behave accordingly.
	For example, <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-svg11">[SVG11]</a> maps its presentation attributes into the <span id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author⑦">author origin</span>.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> Presentational hints entering the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade⑤">cascade</a> as <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-ua" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-ua⑤">UA-origin</a> rules
	can be overridden by <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author⑧">author-origin</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-user" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-user⑤">user-origin</a> styles.
	Presentational hints entering the cascade as <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#author-presentational-hint-origin" id="ref-for-author-presentational-hint-origin①">author presentational hint origin</a> rules
	can be overridden by <span id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author⑨">author-origin</span> styles,
	but not by non-<a data-link-type="dfn" href="#important" id="ref-for-important①⑧">important</a> <span id="ref-for-cascade-origin-user⑥">user-origin</span> styles.
	Host languages should choose the appropriate origin for presentational hints
	with these considerations in mind.</p>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="7" id="defaulting"><span class="secno">7. </span><span class="content"> Defaulting</span><a class="self-link" href="#defaulting"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>When the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade⑥">cascade</a> does not result in a value,
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①②">specified value</a> must be found some other way. <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#inherited-property" id="ref-for-inherited-property">Inherited properties</a> draw their defaults from their parent element through <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#inheritance" id="ref-for-inheritance③">inheritance</a>;
	all other properties take their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#initial-value" id="ref-for-initial-value②">initial value</a>.
	Authors can explicitly request inheritance or initialization
	via the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-inherit" id="ref-for-valdef-all-inherit">inherit</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-initial" id="ref-for-valdef-all-initial">initial</a> keywords.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.1" id="initial-values"><span class="secno">7.1. </span><span class="content"> Initial Values</span><a class="self-link" href="#initial-values"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>Each property has an <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="initial-value">initial value</dfn>,
	defined in the property’s definition table.
	If the property is not an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#inherited-property" id="ref-for-inherited-property①">inherited property</a>,
	and the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade⑦">cascade</a> does not result in a value,
	then the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①③">specified value</a> of the property is its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#initial-value" id="ref-for-initial-value③">initial value</a>.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.2" id="inheriting"><span class="secno">7.2. </span><span class="content"> Inheritance</span><a class="self-link" href="#inheriting"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="inheritance|inherit" id="inheritance">Inheritance</dfn> propagates property values from parent elements to their children.
	The <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="inherited-value">inherited value</dfn> of a property on an element
	is the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#computed-value" id="ref-for-computed-value①③">computed value</a> of the property on the element’s parent element.
	For the root element,
	which has no parent element,
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#inherited-value" id="ref-for-inherited-value">inherited value</a> is the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#initial-value" id="ref-for-initial-value④">initial value</a> of the property.</p>
   <p>For a <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-dom">[DOM]</a> tree with shadows,
	inheritance operates on the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-scoping-1/#flat-tree" id="ref-for-flat-tree①">flattened element tree</a>. <span class="note">This means that slotted elements inherit from the <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/scripting.html#the-slot-element" id="ref-for-the-slot-element">slot</a></code> they’re assigned to,
	rather than directly from their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-light-tree" id="ref-for-concept-light-tree">light tree</a> parent.</span> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors-4/#pseudo-element" id="ref-for-pseudo-element③">Pseudo-elements</a> inherit according to the fictional tag sequence
	described for each <span id="ref-for-pseudo-element④">pseudo-element</span>. <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-pseudo-4">[CSS-PSEUDO-4]</a></p>
   <p>Some properties are <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="inherited property" id="inherited-property">inherited properties</dfn>,
	as defined in their property definition table.
	This means that,
	unless the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade⑧">cascade</a> results in a value,
	the value will be determined by <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#inheritance" id="ref-for-inheritance④">inheritance</a>.</p>
   <p>A property can also be explicitly inherited. See the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-inherit" id="ref-for-valdef-all-inherit①">inherit</a> keyword.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> Inheritance follows the document tree and is not intercepted by <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/visuren.html#box-gen">anonymous boxes</a>,
	or otherwise affected by manipulations of the box tree.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3" id="defaulting-keywords"><span class="secno">7.3. </span><span class="content"> Explicit Defaulting</span><a class="self-link" href="#defaulting-keywords"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>Several CSS-wide property values are defined below;
	declaring a property to have these values explicitly specifies a particular defaulting behavior.
	As specified in <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values/#common-keywords">CSS Values and Units</a> <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-values-3">[css-values-3]</a>,
	all CSS properties can accept these values.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3.1" id="initial"><span class="secno">7.3.1. </span><span class="content"> Resetting a Property: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-initial" id="ref-for-valdef-all-initial①">initial</a> keyword</span><a class="self-link" href="#initial"></a></h4>
   <p>If the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value⑨">cascaded value</a> of a property is
	the <dfn class="caniuse-paneled dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="all" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-all-initial">initial</dfn> keyword,
	the property’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①④">specified value</a> is its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#initial-value" id="ref-for-initial-value⑤">initial value</a>.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3.2" id="inherit"><span class="secno">7.3.2. </span><span class="content"> Explicit Inheritance: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-inherit" id="ref-for-valdef-all-inherit②">inherit</a> keyword</span><a class="self-link" href="#inherit"></a></h4>
   <p>If the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①⓪">cascaded value</a> of a property is
	the <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="all" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-all-inherit">inherit</dfn> keyword,
	the property’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①⑤">specified</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#computed-value" id="ref-for-computed-value①④">computed values</a> are the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#inherited-value" id="ref-for-inherited-value①">inherited value</a>.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3.3" id="inherit-initial"><span class="secno">7.3.3. </span><span class="content"> Erasing All Declarations: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-unset" id="ref-for-valdef-all-unset">unset</a> keyword</span><a class="self-link" href="#inherit-initial"></a></h4>
   <p>If the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①①">cascaded value</a> of a property is
	the <dfn class="caniuse-paneled dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="all" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-all-unset">unset</dfn> keyword,
	then if it is an inherited property, this is treated as <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-inherit" id="ref-for-valdef-all-inherit③">inherit</a>,
	and if it is not, this is treated as <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-initial" id="ref-for-valdef-all-initial②">initial</a>.
	This keyword effectively erases all <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#declared-value" id="ref-for-declared-value⑨">declared values</a> occurring earlier in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade⑨">cascade</a>,
	correctly inheriting or not as appropriate for the property
	(or all longhands of a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#shorthand-property" id="ref-for-shorthand-property①②">shorthand</a>).</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3.4" id="default"><span class="secno">7.3.4. </span><span class="content"> Rolling Back Cascade Origins: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert①">revert</a> keyword</span><a class="self-link" href="#default"></a></h4>
   <p>If the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①②">cascaded value</a> of a property is
	the <dfn class="caniuse-paneled dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="all" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-all-revert">revert</dfn> keyword,
	the behavior depends on the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#origin" id="ref-for-origin①③">cascade origin</a> to which the declaration belongs:</p>
   <dl>
    <dt><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-ua" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-ua⑥">user-agent origin</a> 
    <dd> Equivalent to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-unset" id="ref-for-valdef-all-unset①">unset</a>. 
    <dt><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-user" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-user⑦">user origin</a> 
    <dd> Rolls back the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①③">cascaded value</a> to the user-agent level,
			so that the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①⑥">specified value</a> is calculated
			as if no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author①⓪">author-origin</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-user" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-user⑧">user-origin</a> rules were specified
			for this property on this element. 
    <dt><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author①①">author origin</a> 
    <dd> Rolls back the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①④">cascaded value</a> to the user level,
			so that the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①⑦">specified value</a> is calculated
			as if no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author①②">author-origin</a> rules were specified
			for this property on this element.
			For the purpose of <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert②">revert</a>, this origin includes the Animation <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#origin" id="ref-for-origin①④">origin</a>. 
   </dl>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3.5" id="revert-layer"><span class="secno">7.3.5. </span><span class="content"> Rolling Back Cascade Layers: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert-layer" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert-layer①">revert-layer</a> keyword</span><a class="self-link" href="#revert-layer"></a></h4>
   <p>If the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①⑤">cascaded value</a> of a property is
	the <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="all" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-all-revert-layer">revert-layer</dfn> keyword,
	the <span id="ref-for-cascaded-value①⑥">cascaded value</span> is rolled back to the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers①③">layer</a> below,
	so that the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value①⑧">specified value</a> is calculated
	as if no rules were specified in the current <span id="ref-for-cascade-layers①④">cascade layer</span>—<wbr>or between its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#normal" id="ref-for-normal⑨">normal</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#important" id="ref-for-important①⑨">important</a> levels in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade" id="ref-for-cascade①⓪">cascade</a>—<wbr>for this property on this element.
	For <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert-layer" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert-layer②">revert-layer</a> in <span id="ref-for-important②⓪">important</span> <a href="#style-attr">element-attached styles</a>,
	however,
	it only reverts the <a href="#style-attr">element-attached styles</a> and the intervening <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-animation" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-animation">animation origin</a>,
	and not any of the intervening <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author①③">author-origin</a> <span id="ref-for-important②①">important</span> rules.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> If there are no lower-priority declarations
	in the same <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#origin" id="ref-for-origin①⑤">cascade origin</a> as the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert-layer" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert-layer③">revert-layer</a> value,
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascaded-value" id="ref-for-cascaded-value①⑦">cascaded value</a> will roll back to the previous origin.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span>Note:</span> The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-animation" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-animation①">animation origin</a> is not collapsed with the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-origin-author" id="ref-for-cascade-origin-author①④">author origin</a> for this purpose
	as it is for <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-all-revert" id="ref-for-valdef-all-revert③">revert</a>,
	and thus effectively forms its own <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#cascade-layers" id="ref-for-cascade-layers①⑤">cascade layer</a>.</p>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="8" id="layer-apis"><span class="secno">8. </span><span class="content">Layer APIs</span><a class="self-link" href="#layer-apis"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>



</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="8.1" id="extensions-to-cssimportrule-interface"><span class="secno">8.1. </span><span class="content"> Extensions to the <code>CSSImportRule</code> interface</span><a class="self-link" href="#extensions-to-cssimportrule-interface"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <code>CSSImportRule</code> interface is extended as follows:</p>
<pre class="idl highlight def"><c- b>partial</c-> <c- b>interface</c-> <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="interface" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#cssimportrule" id="ref-for-cssimportrule"><c- g>CSSImportRule</c-></a> {
  <c- b>readonly</c-> <c- b>attribute</c-> <a data-link-type="idl-name" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#cssomstring" id="ref-for-cssomstring"><c- n>CSSOMString</c-></a>? <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="attribute" data-readonly data-type="CSSOMString?" href="#dom-cssimportrule-layername" id="ref-for-dom-cssimportrule-layername"><c- g>layerName</c-></a>;
};
</pre>
   <p>Its <dfn class="dfn-paneled idl-code" data-dfn-for="CSSImportRule" data-dfn-type="attribute" data-export id="dom-cssimportrule-layername"><code>layerName</code></dfn> attribute represents
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name④">layer name</a> declared in the at-rule itself,
	and is an empty string if the layer is anonymous,
	or null if the at-rule does not declare a layer.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="8.2" id="the-csslayerblockrule-interface"><span class="secno">8.2. </span><span class="content"> The <code>CSSLayerBlockRule</code> interface</span><a class="self-link" href="#the-csslayerblockrule-interface"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <code class="idl"><a data-link-type="idl" href="#csslayerblockrule" id="ref-for-csslayerblockrule">CSSLayerBlockRule</a></code> interface represents
	the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer②①">@layer</a> <a href="#layer-block">block rule</a>:</p>
<pre class="idl highlight def">[<a class="idl-code" data-link-type="extended-attribute" href="https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#Exposed" id="ref-for-Exposed"><c- g>Exposed</c-></a>=<c- n>Window</c->]
<c- b>interface</c-> <dfn class="dfn-paneled idl-code" data-dfn-type="interface" data-export id="csslayerblockrule"><code><c- g>CSSLayerBlockRule</c-></code></dfn> : <a data-link-type="idl-name" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#cssgroupingrule" id="ref-for-cssgroupingrule"><c- n>CSSGroupingRule</c-></a> {
  <c- b>readonly</c-> <c- b>attribute</c-> <a data-link-type="idl-name" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#cssomstring" id="ref-for-cssomstring①"><c- n>CSSOMString</c-></a> <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="attribute" data-readonly data-type="CSSOMString" href="#dom-csslayerblockrule-name" id="ref-for-dom-csslayerblockrule-name"><c- g>name</c-></a>;
};
</pre>
   <p>Its <dfn class="dfn-paneled idl-code" data-dfn-for="CSSLayerBlockRule" data-dfn-type="attribute" data-export id="dom-csslayerblockrule-name"><code>name</code></dfn> attribute represents
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name⑤">layer name</a> declared by the at-rule itself,
	and is an empty string if the layer is anonymous.</p>
   <div class="example" id="example-1c46cc0f">
    <a class="self-link" href="#example-1c46cc0f"></a> For example,
	additional nested context is not added from wrapping layer rules. 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- n>@layer</c-> outer <c- p>{</c->
  <c- n>@layer</c-> foo.bar <c- p>{</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>in this case the <code class="idl"><a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-csslayerblockrule-name" id="ref-for-dom-csslayerblockrule-name①">name</a></code> of the inner <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer②②">@layer</a> rule
	is “foo.bar” (and not “outer.foo.bar”).</p>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="8.3" id="the-csslayerstatementrule-interface"><span class="secno">8.3. </span><span class="content"> The <code>CSSLayerStatementRule</code> interface</span><a class="self-link" href="#the-csslayerstatementrule-interface"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <code class="idl"><a data-link-type="idl" href="#csslayerstatementrule" id="ref-for-csslayerstatementrule">CSSLayerStatementRule</a></code> interface represents
	the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#at-ruledef-layer" id="ref-for-at-ruledef-layer②③">@layer</a> <a href="#layer-empty">statement</a>:</p>
<pre class="idl highlight def">[<a class="idl-code" data-link-type="extended-attribute" href="https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#Exposed" id="ref-for-Exposed①"><c- g>Exposed</c-></a>=<c- n>Window</c->]
<c- b>interface</c-> <dfn class="dfn-paneled idl-code" data-dfn-type="interface" data-export id="csslayerstatementrule"><code><c- g>CSSLayerStatementRule</c-></code></dfn> : <a data-link-type="idl-name" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#cssrule" id="ref-for-cssrule"><c- n>CSSRule</c-></a> {
  <c- b>readonly</c-> <c- b>attribute</c-> <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="interface" href="https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#idl-frozen-array" id="ref-for-idl-frozen-array"><c- b>FrozenArray</c-></a>&lt;<a data-link-type="idl-name" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#cssomstring" id="ref-for-cssomstring②"><c- n>CSSOMString</c-></a>> <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="attribute" data-readonly data-type="FrozenArray<CSSOMString>" href="#dom-csslayerstatementrule-namelist" id="ref-for-dom-csslayerstatementrule-namelist"><c- g>nameList</c-></a>;
};
</pre>
   <p>Its <dfn class="dfn-paneled idl-code" data-dfn-for="CSSLayerStatementRule" data-dfn-type="attribute" data-export id="dom-csslayerstatementrule-namelist"><code>nameList</code></dfn> attribute represents
	the list of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#layer-name" id="ref-for-layer-name⑥">layer names</a> declared by the at-rule,
	normalized following the same rule as
	the <code class="idl"><a data-link-type="idl" href="#csslayerblockrule" id="ref-for-csslayerblockrule①">CSSLayerBlockRule</a></code>’s <code class="idl"><a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-csslayerblockrule-name" id="ref-for-dom-csslayerblockrule-name②">name</a></code> attribute.</p>

</details>
